summary: This FBI document details an investigation into Alfredo Rodriguez, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, who attempted to sell documents related to Epstein's civil case to attorney Bradley Edwards for $50,000. Edwards, representing four female plaintiffs, had previously deposed and subpoenaed Rodriguez. The FBI authorized a consensual call and undercover operation to gather evidence of obstruction of justice.

persons.name: Bradley James Edwards
persons.role: Attorney representing plaintiffs in civil case against Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Contacted by Alfredo Rodriguez who tried to sell him documents related to the Epstein case; he informed Rodriguez this was illegal and cooperated with the FBI in an undercover operation.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Attempted to sell documents related to Jeffrey Epstein's civil case to attorney Bradley Edwards for $50,000, leading to an FBI investigation for obstruction of justice.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in a civil case where Bradley Edwards represents four female plaintiffs; his former employee Rodriguez possessed documents related to the case.

connections.description: Edwards, as attorney for plaintiffs suing Epstein, deposed and subpoenaed Rodriguez; Rodriguez then attempted to sell him case documents.
Rodriguez was a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein and possessed documents related to Epstein's case.
Edwards is the attorney representing four female plaintiffs who are suing Jeffrey Epstein in a civil case.

events.title: Rodriguez contacts Edwards to sell documents
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez contacted attorney Bradley Edwards and offered to sell him documents related to the Jeffrey Epstein civil case for $50,000.

events.title: FBI authorizes undercover operation
events.description: The FBI authorized a consensual call and introduction of an undercover employee to complete the document transaction with Rodriguez as part of an obstruction of justice investigation.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, a former Epstein employee, attempted to sell case-related documents to plaintiff's attorney Bradley Edwards for $50,000 in August 2009.
Bradley Edwards informed Rodriguez that his demands were illegal and that he was obligated under a federal subpoena to turn over the documents.
The FBI authorized a consensual monitoring operation involving an undercover employee to gather evidence of obstruction of justice.
The document indicates the investigation was for potential violations of U.S. Code Title 18, Sections 1509 and 1510 (obstruction of justice).
The document contains metadata errors and submission failures, suggesting it was part of an internal FBI reporting system.
